results.title: All over the shop
results.creator_credit: Data Film Productions, European Productivity Agency, J.D. Chambers and Peter Pickering
results.brief_description: Shows examples of how Work Study has been applied in the reorganization of departments in three different firms. In the packing department of a large pharmaceutical works the flow of work was improved, the individual jobs made easier by the use of simple cheap apparatus made for the purpose. Unnecessary movement of personnel was eliminated in the making-up department of a hosiery firm by adoption of a new layout involving the use of conveyor belts. In the sheet metal shop of an electronic instrument firm, Work Study was used to relieve the shortage of skilled operatives.

results.title: All over me
results.creator_credit: Medusa Pictures, Slam Pictures, Baldini Pictures, Dolly Hall and Alex Sichel
results.brief_description: Fifteen year old Claude (Alison Folland) works part time in a pizza shop, lives with her mother in a small apartment in Hell’s Kitchen and loves to jam with her best friend Ellen (Tara Subcoff). However, Claude’s world is starting to change; Claude realises that she has developed stronger feelings for Ellen. Ellen is spending less time with Claude because she has a new boyfriend, Mark, whose aggression and homophobia alienate Claude. Luke (Pat Briggs), a gay musician, has moved into her apartment block and encourages Claude’s interest in music and the world she lives in. When Claude meets Lucy (Leisha Hailey from The Murmers), her recognition of her homosexuality comes to the fore. However, Claude’s world and the people in it are careering out of control; violence abounds and Claude witnesses Ellen’s increasingly complex relationship with drugs. The Sichel sisters, Alex (director) and Sylvia (writer) have created a rites-of-passage film about coming out and growing up in the unforgiving environment of Hell’s Kitchen. The desultory mood of the film and the subtle performance of Folland as Claude launches a dramatic debut feature for the Sichel sisters. (Awards: Winner, Gay Teddy bear at the 1997 Berlin Film Festival)

results.title: All our lives
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB and Sky Works Charitable Foundation
results.brief_description: All of Our Lives examines the reasons why many women face economic hardship and emotional isolation in old age. It is a film about past dreams and, for the most part, unexpected realities. Elderly women from a variety of backgrounds and circumstances recall their girlhood ideals, and contrast them with the experiences of their actual adult lives. The film challenges audiences to re-evaluate the undervalued and often “invisible” world of child-rearing and work in the home.

results.title: All our futures
results.creator_credit: Harold Mantell Inc and Harold Mantell
results.brief_description: Narrated by Peter Ustinov this film shows the 25 years of service to children by UNICEF. Beginning in 12 European countries where five million children were given food, medicine and clothing during the emergency period after World War II, and then moving - over the years and to many different places - to show its diversified work in many more countries including Africa and Latin America.

results.brief_description: Shows how new approaches in art education in Victoria can be successfully applied in the classroom. As the new course is child-centred, the film visualises some of the environmental influences that children experience

results.title: All my own work
results.brief_description: An in-service education film for teachers. Aims to show how the new approaches in Art Education can be successfully applied to the classroom. The emphasis is on painting, while the new course is child-centered.

results.title: All my own bush
results.brief_description: A Secondary School student takes a movie camera to the bushland around Monbulk and is suddenly aware of man’s intrusion into the bush. Suitable for mid-upper Primary School.

results.title: All men are liars
results.creator_credit: Arena Films, John Maynard and Gerard Lee
results.brief_description: In an attempt to reunite his family, which has fallen apart over a hocked piano, sensitive 17 year old Mick O’Brien joins the all girl “Total Fire Band” to earn some extra cash. He falls in love with the lead singer Angela whos been jilted by one too many lying men. She’s hot for Mick too, but not because hes cute and talented, but being a woman he’s sure to be honest! Great performances from Toni Pearen and especially John Jarrat as the has-been Elvis impersonator adds to the hilarity of this left-of-centre comedy.
